metadata.title: Detection of SARS-COV-2 in Placental and Fetal Membrane Samples

body_text.text: CoV-2 and its associated disease , concerns remain about whether the virus 14 is transmissible in pregnant women from the mother to the fetus during either the 15 antepartum period or the process of labor and delivery. One recent review reported that 16 in a small number of cases, two PCR swabs of the placenta were sent in additional to 17 neonatal and cord blood testing, and both placental PCR swabs were negative. 1 Other 18 studies have demonstrated the finding of SARS-CoV2 IgM in neonates born to mothers 19 diagnosed with COVID-19 during pregnancy, 2,3 findings that may indicate vertical 20 transmission of the virus in utero. We report our experience with placental/membrane 21 SARS-CoV2 RNA PCR swab results after delivery to a series of symptomatic mothers 22
body_text.section: Detection of SARS-COV-2 in Placental and Fetal Membrane Samples

body_text.text: with confirmed COVID-19 infection in pregnancy. 23
body_text.section: Detection of SARS-COV-2 in Placental and Fetal Membrane Samples

body_text.text: Methods: IRB approval was obtained. All pregnant patients diagnosed with COVID-19 24 who gave birth between March 1, 2020 and April 20, 2020 at NYU Langone Health were 25 identified by a search of the electronic medical record. Charts were reviewed for 26 documentation of SARS-CoV-2 RNA RT-PCR testing sent from either the placenta or 27 membranes within 30 minutes following delivery. PCR testing for SARS-COV-2 was 28 performed using the cobas SARS-CoV-2 assay (Roche) or the Cepheid Xpert Xpress 29 assay. Placental swabs were obtained from the amniotic surface after clearing the surface 30 of maternal blood (placental PCR). Membrane swabs were obtained from between the 31 amnion and chorion after manual separation of the membranes (membrane PCR). 32
body_text.section: Detection of SARS-COV-2 in Placental and Fetal Membrane Samples

body_text.text: Maternal COVID-19 illness was categorized as mild, severe, or critical. 4 The time 33
body_text.section: Detection of SARS-COV-2 in Placental and Fetal Membrane Samples

body_text.text: interval from maternal diagnosis of COVID-19 to delivery was calculated in days. Infants 34 were tested with nasopharyngeal swabs for SARS-CoV-2 PCR between days of life 1 and 5 while hospitalized. Hospitalized infants were also assessed for clinical signs and 36 symptoms, including fever, cough, and nasal congestion. 37
body_text.section: Detection of SARS-COV-2 in Placental and Fetal Membrane Samples

body_text.text: Results: Of 32 COVID-19 positive pregnant patients who gave birth in this timeframe, 38 placental or membrane swabs were sent from 11 patients (Table) Although all of our neonates tested negative in the first 5 days of life, many were born via 53 cesarean deliveries with decreased length of exposure to these tissues, which may be 54

FIGREF0.text: Since the first reports of the emergence of the novel coronavirus SARS-13

FIGREF1.text: . Three of 11 swabs were 39 positive. None of the infants tested positive for SARS-CoV2 on days of life 1 through 5, 40 and none demonstrated symptoms of COVID-19 infection. 41 Discussion: Of 11 placental or membrane swabs sent following delivery, 3 swabs were 42 positive for SARS-CoV-2, all in women with moderate to severe COVID-19 illness at 43 time of delivery. This is the first study to demonstrate the presence of SARS-CoV-2 RNA 44 in placental or membrane samples. While there were no clinical signs of vertical 45 transmission, our findings raise the possibility of intrapartum viral exposure. Given the 46 mixing of maternal and fetal fluid and tissue at time of delivery, the origin of the detected 47 SARS-CoV-2 RNA in our series is unclear. It may represent contamination from 48 maternal blood, amniotic fluid, or COVID-19 infection of the membranes and amniotic 49 sac. For those infants who were delivered vaginally, contamination with vaginal 50 secretions is also a possible source, although prior studies on vaginal secretions have 51 failed to demonstrate the presence of COVID-19. 5,6 52

FIGREF2.text: associated with a decreased likelihood of vertical transmission. Additionally, 55 nasopharyngeal testing immediately after delivery may not be the ideal approach to 56 evaluate vertical transmission if exposure occurs at the time of delivery, as the virus may 57 require a longer incubation period before these swabs convert to positive. In summary, the presence of viral RNA by RT-PCR in placenta/membranes at the time of delivery 59 suggests the need for further research into the possibility of vertical transmission.
